awd_titl_txt: Particle and Quantum Field Theory Investigations
awd_abstract_narration:
This award funds the research activities of Professors S. Dubovskiy, G. Gabadadze, M. Porrati, and A. Sirlin at New York University. 

The research activities of these four investigators center around several topics aimed at answering some of the truly fundamental questions in physics: How to best determine the fundamental constants of nature? What is the correct theory of gravity? What is gravity at cosmic scales? How is cosmology constrained by string theory or quantum gravity? Are there different models that explain the past and present accelerated expansion of the Universe? How can we describe strongly interacting subatomic matter? Can quantum gravity be solved in simple "toy model" settings? The PIs will work towards answering these questions both in parallel and in collaboration, involving postdocs and graduate students in the research process. As a result, research in this area advances the national interest by promoting the progress of science in one of its most fundamental directions: the discovery and understanding of new physical laws. This project is also envisioned to have significant broader impacts, including the training of a new generation of scientists at all levels. Dissemination of results will also include review articles for specialized and popular science journals, organization of workshops, video- and Internet-based courses, and popular lectures. 

More technically, Professor Dubovskiy will continue to study many aspects of a special deformation of quantum field theories, called "T-T bar," and its applications to two-dimensional gravity, confining strings, and to a novel perspective on the hierarchy and cosmological-constant problems. Professor Gabadadze will search for possible UV-complete theories of massive gravity, and study holographic QCD as well as a theory of condensed-matter systems giving rise to equations for their sound modes that are identical to the ones Hawking solved to predict black-hole radiation.  Professor Porrati will study simple models of gravity and supergravity, the infrared dynamics of gravity and ague theories, inflation in supergravity, and the link between massive gravity in three dimensions and conformal field theories.  Professor Sirlin will apply a novel approach to evaluate electroweak corrections in important elementary particle-physics processes.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The grant covered a large part of research in theoretical physics at New York University. It consisted of several topics, some interrelated some complementary to each other but all aimed at answer fundamental questions in physics. Research supported by this grant advanced national interest by promoting the progress of science in one of its most fundamental directions: the discovery and understanding of new physical laws The PIs worked towards answering these questions both in parallel and in collaboration, structurally involving and training postdocs and graduate students, who profited of their training to further their research and academic career and have often moved on to research position in major research centers and universities. Dissemination of research results occured through review articles published in specialized and popular-science journals as well as through the organization of workshops, video- and Internet-based courses, and popular lectures.

Porrati (MP), together with postdocs and graduate students, studied and made progress on several projects devoted to understanding theories that combine gravity with quantum mechanics. MP specifically studied: 1) The  long-distance dynamics of gravity, with the aim of  determining what is truly observable in gravitational scattering. 2) Gravity beyond the regime where Einstein's theory is a good approximation, in a simplified spacetime with only two space dimension. 3) Simple toy models of gravity in which space is locally exactly flat yet black holes exist. These toy models allow to study gravity in a strongly quantum regime. The same models are also essential to understand topological phases in condensed matter physics, so any progress made in understanding them has multidisciplinary applications. 4) Models of the presently most successful cosmological model, called slow-roll inflation, that incorporate two key ingredients believed to be necessary in a truly fundamental theory that explains the big bang: supersymmetry and supergravity.  The investigations conducted by MP his students and postdocs, resulted in several research papers published in major refereed journals.

Sirlin's research on the discrepancy of theory predictions and and experiment for the anomalous magnetic moment of the muon excluded new physics sources in large energy ranges by a careful analysis of all existing theoretical and experimental data.

Gabadadze planned to study: 1) Extensions of the so-called Conformal Galileon theories -- used in astrophysics and cosmology -- to a broader class of theories containing the spinless particles called Conformal Galileons as a subset. 2) To study certain theories of gravity that extend Einstein's General Relativity 3) To propose an extension of massive General Relativity to a theory that would be as good as the former all the way up to a very high energy scale.               
These goals produced papers in which: 1) Gabadadze and Tukhashvili constructed a full-fledged gravitational field theory that contains the Conformal Galileon as its subset. They established the limits of applicability of  this theory and worked out its potential cosmological implications.  2) Alexander, Gabadadaze, Jenks, and Yunes studied Black Holes in dynamical Chern-Simons gravity and found their novel features. It turns out that such Black Holes develop caps near their north and south poles. The authors studied superradiance from such Black Holes. 3) Gabadadze, Older, and Pirtskhalava studied an extension of massive General Relativity  with desirable properties and applicable to astrophysics and cosmology.

Dubovsky's research covered two broad topics. The first one is the study of the dynamics of confining flux tubes in quantum chromodynamics (QCD), and of the connections between the flux tube properties and the observed spectrum of strongly interacting particles.The second topic is the absence of static tidal forces of black holes in general relativity, implying that in the static limit they behave as point-like absorbing objects.
As far as the first topic goes, Dubovsky (together with his Ph.D. student Donahue), constructed and solved a novel integrable relativistic quantum mechanical system---the Zigzag model. This model provides the leading high energy approximation to the flux tube dynamics in two dimensional QCD, and is expected to capture many features of the flux tube dynamics in higher dimensions. Also in collaboration with Ph.D student Conkey and also with Teper he performed lattice simulations, which provided a convincing support of the earlier proposal for the structure of the glueball spectrum in 3d QCD.   Furthermore, in collaboration with a current Ph.D. student (Zare) and with a former one (Hernandez--Chifflet) he achieved a better understanding of the relation between this proposal and the effective theory of closed strings, and identified surprising differences betwen the two. For the second topic, in collaboration with a Ph.D. student (Charalambous) and a postdoc (Ivanov), Dubovsky resolved an ongoing controversy and established that rotating black holes also exhibit vanishing static conservative tidal responses. Furthermore, they managed to identify a novel approximate hidden symmetry explaining the vanishing of the black hole's static tidal responses.
